The function \( y = \sin\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) \) has x-intercepts where \( \sin\left(\frac{1}{x}\right) = 0 \), which occurs when \( \frac{1}{x} = n\pi \) for integer \( n \). Thus, \( x = \frac{1}{n\pi} \). For \( x \) in \( (0.0001, 0.001) \), we find \( n \) such that \( 319 \leq n \leq 3183 \). The number of integers in this range is \( 3183 - 319 + 1 = 2865 \).

\boxed{2865}

So, in the interval from 0.0001 to 0.001, which is quite close to zero, the function sin(1/x) will have a lot of oscillations, hence many zeros. So, 2865 intercepts seems plausible. The integers \( n \) range from 319 to 3183, inclusive. The number of integers is \( 3183 - 319 + 1 = 2865 \).
